Author: Gateway#3763

[dscrdvrsc] <englal> There are two particularly safe approaches -
you can mine with both wallets, then merge them later
or you can have one wallet on one computer, and have the other computer(s) mine to an address in the one wallet

Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> It's not that big a task.   Especially with hte 600 GH/s net hash

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> Think of the blockchain as a huge serialized set of bank safe deposit boxes.   Your PRIV KEY is needed for each box (address) that you own.  The address is the PUBLIC key, but the only way to get what's in the boxes is with both the public and the private keys.  The wallet  is your set of keys.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> Anyone can search using your public key and see a transaction.   But only someone with the private key can move the contents.

Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> No.  They need your wallet data.  They can hack you or steal your laptop.... but they need the wallet.dat file.   If they get that then it is theirs.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> Just like if someone stole my keychain.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> Of course, the bank will ID me and check my signature.... but same idea
